job_title: Project Administrator in Belfast, Northern Ireland

cons: Large organisation which struggles with team culture

review_title: OK for some but better jobs out there.
job_title: Clerical Officer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good holidays, good pension and some homeworking.
cons: It has an awful HR department who tend to do bare minimum and pat themselves on the back for being awful. Low pay in most clerical jobs and terrible promotion opportunities, most jobs fixed term then they recruit more. Better opportunities in Civil Service or private sector. Pension is good but they take 9 percent off your salary which is already very low. Lots of bureaucracy and several people doing jobs above their abilities. Queens say they only recruit the best which is an absolute joke as many of these people wouldnt get jobs anywhere. About 90 per cent of office roles are taken by middle aged women. Interviewing staff are unprofessional and rude and dont abide by normal practices, in fact anyone can be an interviewer after completing a short online course. Queens absolutely love international students as it is nothing more than a money making machine.

job_title: Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: - Supervisors are generally supportive with the project that is assigned, and are open to funding additional courses if it pertains to the project.
cons:
- Depending on which research group you are assigned to, there is a wide variance. The group I was assigned in was a relative skeleton crew, and the work load is quite heavy that essentially encompasses technician work. This makes things difficult; especially if the contracts are short-term.

- External characterization facilities are lacking. While recent booking systems are very good, but certain equipment gets broken down frequently which limits what can be done. They also appear to be working with a small crew which means certain equipment have been down for years.

job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Queen's community is a very supportive and collaborative environment. My colleagues and authorities are very aware about the importance of academic standards in teaching, research, service and contact with the professional and non-professional community at both local and international levels. Authorities are very approachable and friendly (and don't confuse that with being informal, arbitrary or not serious as that's not the case for Queen's). This is somehow an ideal workplace (leaving aside our common consensus that there are not perfect workplaces on earth). High quality of research (impact, research funding and quality of publication), high levels of student satisfaction and constant professional accreditation to ensure quality of teaching and accomplishment of professional requirements of industry.

PS: Belfast is such a wonderful city (beautiful, walkable, human-scale, affordable and surrounded by very beautiful landscapes). That makes the work-life balance really good.
cons:
(1) It seems to be a bit geographically away from other research centres in EU, but not really a big issue. There are good connections with Ulster University and the Republic of Ireland. The rest are just a few hours flying. 
(2) Buildings and infrastructure in general are a bit old (like almost in the entire UK), but not a big issue as this is still OK with the living and working standards.
(3) The weather: nothing to say, nothing to do with this. Autumn and winter is nevertheless beautiful in parks and the river. Just apply the Nordic premise: there is not bad weather, there is only bad clothing.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
QUB is a great place to work in the tech side of things.

There are some unique and fantastic opportunities to work on some amazing projects.

You are given a lot of autonomy to investigate new technology and to see if it adds value to the University. 

You get to work with fantastic academics and students who are working on interesting areas. 

Work life balance is incredible, with the most generous leave entitlement anywhere in tech in Belfast, amazing pension, health care perks and discounts on QUB facilities (e.g. QFT, PEC). QUB also have the best staff well being program I've seen. 

Interestingly, pay is also competitive (sometimes better) when compared to the likes of older tech companies in Belfast (looking at you AllState, Kainos and Liberty) who still seem to benchmark off each other for payscales, and don't factor in the rapidly expanding tech sector in Belfast and the competitive market in terms of salary. Relative to the aforementioned companies, QUB (for tech roles) pays reasonably well.
cons: Honestly can't think of any.

job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Good work life balance
Benefits like cycle to work scheme
cons: Salary lower than GB counterparts

job_title: Research Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Best staff and good facilities
cons: Options for contract staff to get permanent

job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Potentially a great university. Most staff working at Queen's are dedicated and working very hard. Many staff have dedicated their lives to improving the university and should be better appreciated. The possibilities are enormous if there is more collegiality and cooperation encouraged between staff.
cons:
Sadly the senior management do not appreciate what they have. Almost all of the senior management from the new Vice Chancellor down are from Northern Ireland. They have a very narrow outlook and cannot or refuse to see themselves as others do.  This is very apparent to outsiders.  Do not come here if you cannot fit in.
Also ask about the performance management targets - especially the income targets and support before going there. Not meeting these will lead to aggressive capability procedures and dismissal so be warned. No one is secure.
Sad to leave but I could not fit in - despite doing very well - the future was not secure there. There was little real support and guidance available at Queen's.  Despite being OK on targets the performance management pressures on some colleagues had become unacceptable. 
Another UK employer is now providing much better support and understanding.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in London, England
pros: A wonderful place to spend time
cons: A wonderful place to spend time away from

review_title: Fantastic Staff but a dreadful working environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: The staff were absolutely fantastic and the holidays were excellent. The support that the university gave you if you had any personal or family issues was also excellent.
cons: What I experienced as employee in QUB was nothing short of a disgrace. The communication around various issues surrounding the university was nothing short of shocking. Staff would look at the BBC website for university related issues,  rather than wait for an email from the communications department. It was always emails little dialogue. Senior Management were as poor as I have ever worked with in an organisation. There was little or no cohesion or team work and that was not due to staff willingness. There were plenty of highly skilled, experienced people in my department that treated like children, being man managed with absolutely no autonomy offered. Appraisals were abysmal, I was being appraised by someone who no managerial experience and hadn't even received appraisal training.  To get things signed off or to purchase items was a long laborious process with rafts of red tape.

review_title: Only work here if you're from NI or into supernovae
job_title: PDRA in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
The cost of living in Belfast is low.
The university is situated in a very picturesque part of town.
There are plenty of extra-curricular activities to get involved in.
Generous with computing equipment.
cons:
If you don't work in supernovae, you will feel increasingly marginalised working here.
The department has a very low gender diversity (one female academic), a very low ethnic diversity and most people are from the local region. I've never known a Russell Group university to be so insular.
Lack of support.
Lack of respect.
Lack of social activities.
No integration of PDRAs into the departmental functioning.

review_title: Good employer, but like all academia massive amounts of admin
job_title: Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Nice boss, good fun with co-workers, easy to get holidays and time off and a laid back atmosphere.
cons: moderate pay, little or no work-life balance and trying to get something done takes months and dozens of people! No coordination on the online services. There are 4 different things you need to log into every morning just to stay up to date. The learning and career development modules are also no use. There are probably loads of things available to you.. but I've no idea where to find out about it or who to ask!

review_title: Do not take care of staff
job_title: Research Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: The new developments to the campus are nice, there is a lot of money going towards improving buildings etc. which makes the work environment nicer
cons: Research staff are under a lot of pressure to bring in big grants and lot of people are overworked. On top of this holidays are being cut. There is nothing worse for moral than coming into work on a bank holiday when everyone else has the day off. In my department staff are leaving like rats off a sinking ship.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: I have been working as a postdoc for 2 years at QUB. The atmosphere is good and there are departments dedicated to training, prepare fellowships or build your professional plan. The people working there are very helpful.
cons: There is not much funding available to go to conferences or training sessions outside QUB. For postdocs there are no permanent positions available apart from (very few and highly competitive) lecturer's positions.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: A university with great reputation and relatively good working environment for a job of this nature. You come across some really interesting people and extremely rewarding when you see your students do well during the course and after it.
cons: Quite unfair for Teaching Assistants in terms of the benefits TAs get when a large proportion of teaching responsibility is on TAs. No office. No printing facilities. No storage for work-related things. No access to information crucial to teaching.

review_title: Disorganised, rude admin staff, discrimination and toxic working environment.
job_title: in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Pay is good, you may be lucky - some departments can be nice to work in but these are rare at QUB as the toxic environment starts at the top and flows downstream.
cons: Almost everything. Awful and immoral culture full of people fudging their work, lying and bullying others to cover up for their own insecurities and inadequacies.

review_title: Mediocre research envirionment and over bureucratic
job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Belfast is a good city to live in, people are friendly in general and cost of living is among the lowest in the UK. There are incentives in terms of salaries and seed grants etc to encourage staff to stay.
cons: Isolated if you want to do good quality research. Top heavy administration creating an environment of mistrust with unreasonable and over exaggerated expectations. Difficult to get high quality jobs outside University if you have a two body problem.

review_title: Great place to work if you are in the right team
job_title: in Belfast City Centre, Northern Ireland
pros:
Flexible working time 
Opportunities to go to international conferences
cons: Most of the supervisor , line managers extremely too busy to get involved and support the postodoc. Takes ages to get  things sorted out . Depends on the team you are working with ,but some people are a bit mean. Hard to progress if you are part of a team who is not supporting you and this will affect your future career .

review_title: Great work environment, great people to work with
job_title: Software Developer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
-Great training
-Friendly atmosphere
-Plenty of resources for learning
-Wide variety of work
-Plenty of support from management
-Very flexible with hours and with holidays
cons: - Probably wasn't there long enough to know if there is much room for career progression, but people will usually know some of the limits of working within a university compared to a business. However its hard for me to fault them

review_title: Lovely place if you know the right people..!
job_title: Research Engineer in Queens Island, Northern Ireland
pros: Flexibility and understanding management. Excellent sports facilities that staff are encouraged to try. Close to all facilities such as restaurants et al. Great sub teams such as with in private accommodation and estates.
cons: Not much in terms of work/life balance. Could be more hands on in terms of instruction but is respectable within a university environment.  IT managers very protective of their work as elsewhere but paper work is sometimes too bureaucratic.

review_title: More value on appearance and marketing than teaching and research
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Good marketing
Good appearance
Affordable (student) accommodations
Good for environmental sciences, cancer and parasitology.
cons:
Teaching and research facilities not related to cancer, parasitology or environmental/agricultural/pharmaceutical research are of low priority to the University --> Missing/Outdated/Insufficient laboratory equipment.
Overly bureaucratic without obvious benefits.
Very basic postgraduate teaching (MS Office, Basic graphic design, plagiarism, etc.) but little to no specialised courses for scientific tools/techniques (i.e. no bioinformatics courses, no methodology workshops, etc.).
Treats research more like a business than an academic endeavour.

review_title: A predictably strong working experience at a top UK university.
job_title: Student Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Working for Queen's University allowed me to effectively balance work and study due to the university's excellent student jobshop. By concentrating working hours outside of term time and only allowing 15 hours of work  per week the university ensured that working life did not interfere with my education.
cons: Wages are paid one month in arrears. While standard for this type of work, the delay in payment was nevertheless somewhat disappointing.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
The buildings are nice.  In fact the physical environment is very attractive and getting better all the time, as one would expect of an institution spending £30 million a year on bricks and mortar.

If you are lucky, as I was, your immediate team might be a great group of committed, talented, and energetic scholars and teachers, and your students likewise. 

Belfast is a nicer city than you might think.
cons:
The academic working environment has been deteriorating rapidly and will continue to do so as the current CEO's "vision" limps like a wounded dog toward full implementation. Over the next 18 months a number incredibly wasteful, overlapping, and insular layers of bureaucracy in three faculty silos will settle in (four new deans, an operations manager, professional services teams, etc. etc. for each faculty). All this on top of the existing hierarchy. Communication and operations within and between these layers and with staff at the coalface of teaching and research is utterly dysfunctional. There is a profound disregard for and ignorance of the work and ethos of the core human resource of the University: the disciplinary researcher and teacher. 

Any person considering taking up a lectureship at this University should seek the following information and reflect on it carefully, comparing it to competing institutions if possible:

*Is the student intake on your teaching programmes stable or declining? What are the commitments and strategies for marketing these programmes? How does the programme websites compare to its competitors? Is the University leveraging its location and its human resources effectively?

*How stable is the academic team you will be joining?  Are your future colleagues satisfied with the direction the University is going?  How many are actively seeking work elsewhere?  Have many people left the programme recently? Why?

*If you are at entry level: are the requirements (teaching, admin, research) to pass probation within a two year period reasonable?  How do they compare with competing institutions?  What has been the recent experience of academics on probation in your programme?  What tangible support mechanisms are in place to help you succeed (curricular development, teaching assistance, financial support for research material and travel, ring-fencing of research time)? 

*If you are an established researcher, with the aspiration to win external research grants: how does the University handle the income you will generate?  Talk to current grant holders about their experience.  Ask them about support for managing the paperwork and the people. Ask them whether they have actually got the relief from teaching and admin specified in the grant they have won. Find out whether the institution values your research, or just your research income. 

If you do your homework about working in Queen's, you may find,  like I have, that there are better places to be.

job_title: Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good work-life balance, good ethic, good conditions of work, professional HR department.
cons: Queen's strives to be a top research institution, but there are numerous challenges along the way -- the infrastructure is not in place for world-class research in my field, and there is little support from technical staff when you need it. There is also too much internal competition and too little collaboration, The is not unusual for a research institution, but still an issue.

review_title: Minimal support and unreasonable demands on output
job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Location: Northern Ireland is a beautiful place and Belfast as a city has improved a lot. 
Infrastructure: The university has some nice buildings, ranging from old architectural gems (Lanyon Building) to modern new buildings (like the ones behind the MBC on Lisburn Road).
Dedicated and hard-working staff.
cons: The management (at the university, faculty and school levels) is the weakest spot of this place. Beware especially if you are a new lecturer - at this university your career may go up in smoke before it has properly started. They will be happy to take you onboard and will promise you beautiful things. Make sure you get them all in writing, otherwise the chances are they won't materialise. The management will be happy to include you into the REF return (this is probably the primary reason why they got you) - your publications from your previous place of work is what they need. But the support you may get to develop your own research and lab there may be ridiculous compared to what you would get elsewhere. However, their demands on the output and grant income will be unrealistically high and out of touch with real life. All that counts is the grant money you can bring. Don't bother with investing too much time and energy into teaching - it doesn't count for much in the eyes of the bean counters sitting in the administrative building. The administration of research is painfully slow, so don't be surprised if it takes weeks or even months to arrange relatively straightforward matters. Tough luck if you have to explain this to your collaborators overseas. To paraphrase one of the previous reviews, at Queen's it means a lot who you know and who knows you. It is a small world in Northern Ireland and those who were born there either all know each other or are related to each other (or go to the same church - that too seems to play a role). Avoid if you can.

job_title: KTP Associate in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good  training and exposure to new technologies.  Great plan for the KTP program itself and I learned alot. Would recommend over most graduate programmes as this did offer me access to great job oppertunities.
cons: My KTP advisior was off/away for some of my KTP and never got really hands on.  Also only a 2 year contract.

job_title: PhD Student in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good lecturers, good research staff, great administration staff. Most lecturers are really helpful if you ask them questions about the weekly assignments.
cons: Some lecturers are more interested in their own research or work rather than their lectures, and so some are unapproachable.

review_title: Great place to work, demanding but also rewarding
job_title: Internal Recruiter in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Opportunity to work on projects outside own role to develop experience without necessarily changing job is very positive
It is great to be part of a team who are helping form and improve the world we live in. 
Employee benefits are good e.g. pension, O2 contract discount, incremental progression
cons: Limited parking in the local area

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: QUB provides an excellent environment to work in with academic freedom and encouragement to develop and innovate.
cons: Too many centralised functions and paperwork.  Ironically a process designed to make efficiencies leads to many many more pointless meetings and paperwork (admin?) for academics all the while the central administration growing in number and incompetence.

review_title: Very Aggressive Management and getting worse
job_title: Professor in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Sports centre is good
Good if you like admin and its highly rewarded
You can get on well if you get lucky and get in with the right people
cons:
Academic standards along with capability management mean no job security and little academic freedom
The management are very very aggressive especially the top executives.
Hard to get even the most basic of promotions
Staff are demoralised, generally

job_title: PhD Researcher in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
Lots of opportunity for professional and personal development through the graduate school.

Everyone wants you to succeed and as a result everyone is willing to help with any problems.
cons:
Long hours.

It's to be expected when working in a scientific setting. Can be difficult to juggle social life/exercise with the job but certainly not impossible!

job_title: Research Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Excellent salary with good work-life balance
cons: Work politics is horrible with bad managers. Research life is like without any freedom and PI controls everything with a line manager. I had to get the HR involved to sort out my issues with my managers. No carrer progression was possible.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: World renowned institution. Great 'community feel' on campus, among both staff and students with excellent facilities that staff can avail from.
cons: It can take a long time to get things certain things done or approved, especially if numerous departments are involved. Can be hard to advance in certain fields.

job_title: Lecturer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Like most academic jobs, the flexibility to do what you want is amazing. Everyday has a new and exciting discovery.
cons: Queens University Belfast is a mid-tier University whose funding is determined by idiots in Stormont. Therefore funding is stretched and you need to count the pennies.

review_title: Cutting edge academic R&D in QAMEC
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Passionate informed leadership combined with cutting edge facilities enable an environment conducive to world-leading research in semiconductors and microtechnology
cons: The University Management Committee don't seem to be able to catch the vision, resulting in somewhat lacking toplevel support

job_title: Admin Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Learnt basic admin skills.
cons: No progression. Test needed to get promoted are carried out on an awful old system making them incredibly difficult to pass. Wages are very low.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Flexible working, interesting and varied work, people generally friendly. MBC is located in nice area close to town and shops
cons: some suspicion between staff members and a definite "click" in certain departments. Once funding is up you have no job.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: It depends on a group, some are good some are not good enough but just they exists
cons: Unfoetunately, even though university creates itself as an open and friendly enviroment, there is stil much to do with an equality

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland

cons: Fixed term contracts. It is almost impossible to get a lectureship, even if you have had a solid post doc career!

job_title: PhD Student in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
local people are friendly to oversea students
low living cost
lots of pubs

inconvenient location, need to fly to other UK/EU cities
industry is not very strong

job_title: Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good place to work. Flexible working hours.  No working time restriction as long as you achieve the objective.
cons: Very limited chances for career progression. Lots of politics if apply for promotion or higher rank position.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Great working environment, friendly staff, great mentoring available, recognition of hard work
cons: More parking needs to be available for staff as during the term time, parking is hard to come by with students

job_title: Professor in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: A great institution with a strong ethos - some committed colleagues who work hard - students work hard and provide vibrant atmosphere - strong sense of loyalty amongst many staff.  Huge potential.
cons: Aggressive performance management. Management obsessed with metrics. Aggressive and uncaring management that condones bullying.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Colleagues are friendly, nice relaxed environment to work in, good pay for the work that you do
cons: Lack of career progression due to certain personnel being in top positions

review_title: Great place to work with good research environment
job_title: PhD Student in Belfast, Northern Ireland

review_title: Good university with a lot of admin
